title: 113_hr3202
content: The Act is titled the "Essential Transportation Worker Identification Credential Assessment Act" and includes a comprehensive security assessment of the Transportation Security Card Program. The Secretary of Homeland Security must provide a comprehensive assessment of the transportation security card program's effectiveness in enhancing security for regulated facilities and vessels. The Secretary of Homeland Security must conduct a comprehensive assessment of the transportation security card program's effectiveness in enhancing security for regulated facilities and vessels. The assessment will be carried out by a national laboratory or maritime security university-based center within the Department of Homeland Security. The Secretary of Homeland Security will conduct a comprehensive assessment of the transportation security card program's effectiveness in addressing security risks in the maritime environment, addressing deficiencies, and conducting a cost-benefit analysis. A corrective action plan and program reforms must be implemented within 60 days of the assessment submission. The Secretary of Homeland Security will submit a corrective action plan to address identified deficiencies in the transportation security card program within 60 days of the assessment submission. The plan will include an implementation plan with benchmarks and a cost-benefit analysis of the program. The House of Representatives and Senate committees will respond to the assessment with a corrective action plan, including implementation steps, programmatic reforms, and legislative proposals. The plan will be reviewed by the Comptroller General within 120 days. The Comptroller General will review the corrective action plan within 120 days to assess the implementation of recommendations from national laboratories, maritime security centers, and previous Comptroller General recommendations. The findings will be reported to the House Committees on Homeland Security and Transportation and Infrastructure. The Comptroller General will review the corrective action plan within 120 days to assess the implementation of recommendations from national laboratories, maritime security centers, and previous Comptroller General recommendations. The findings will be reported to relevant House and Senate committees. The Secretary of Homeland Security is prohibited from issuing a final rule on transportation security card readers until the Comptroller General informs the Committees. The Secretary of Homeland Security is prohibited from issuing a final rule on transportation security card readers until the Comptroller General informs the Committees on Homeland Security and Transportation and Infrastructure of the House of Representatives and Commerce, Science and Transportation of the Senate that the submission is responsive to recommendations. The Secretary of Homeland Security is prohibited from issuing a final rule on transportation security card readers until the Comptroller General confirms that the submission is responsive to recommendations. Additionally, the Secretary must update the list of compatible transportation security card readers. This does not apply to any final rule issued for TWIC-Reader Requirements by the Coast Guard on March 22, 2013. The Comptroller General will provide oversight every six months for three years after issuing a corrective action plan regarding Transportation Worker Identification Credential (TWIC)-Reader Requirements. The Comptroller General will report every six months for three years to the relevant committees on the implementation of the corrective action plan for TWIC-Reader Requirements. SEC. 3. NO ADDITIONAL FUNDS AUTHORIZED. This Act and its amendments will be carried out using existing funds, without any additional appropriations.
